content: The Act may be cited as the "Cord Blood Stem Cell Act of 2003". The findings are also included in the Act. Research sponsored by the National Institutes of Health has shown the feasibility of using cord blood for clinical applications, including bone marrow reconstitution for certain diseases. Stem cells from cord blood can be used for transplantation in conditions like leukemia, lymphoma, sickle cell anemia, and other acquired diseases. Cord blood, collected from the umbilical cord and donated by the mother, is a source of stem cells used for bone marrow reconstitution in recipients with malignancies, genetic disorders, and acquired diseases. This cord blood can be preserved through freezing for many years and is readily available for transplantation. Cord blood, a source of stem cells, can be collected from residual neonatal blood without risk to the donor. It can be preserved through freezing for many years and used for transplantation in clinical situations or scientific research. Advantages of cord blood stem cell transplants include reduced risks to the donor, quicker availability of donor cell units, and lower transplant complications compared to bone marrow transplants. Advantages of cord blood stem cell transplants over bone marrow transplants include reduced risks to the donor, quicker availability of donor cell units, and lower transplant complications such as graft versus host disease and latent virus infections. Cord blood stem cell banks offer increased genetic diversity in donor supply, allowing for fully matched or partially matched transplants. Cord blood stem cell banks provide an opportunity to identify fully matched and partially matched transplant units for qualified candidates. Research on cord blood stem cells may lead to a greater understanding of chronic diseases like Parkinson's disease, diabetes, heart disease, and cancer, potentially improving therapies and finding cures. These diseases contribute significantly to chronic disabilities and healthcare costs in the United States. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a National Cord Blood Stem Cell Bank Network. The National Cord Blood Stem Cell Bank Network is defined by key terms such as Administrator, cord blood unit, donor, and donor bank. The National Cord Blood Stem Cell Bank Network includes terms such as donor bank, human cord blood stem cells, and qualified cord blood stem cell banks. The National Cord Blood Stem Cell Bank Network is a network of qualified cord blood stem cell banks established to contain at least 150,000 units of human cord blood stem cells. The National Network of Cord Blood Stem Cell Banks aims to establish and maintain at least 150,000 units of human cord blood stem cells. The purpose of the donor banks is to acquire, test, store, and preserve donated cord blood units in compliance with regulations. The National Network of Cord Blood Stem Cell Banks aims to store donated units of human cord blood in compliance with regulations. The banks make cord blood units available for transplantation and allocate a portion for research each year. Eligible donor banks must meet federal and state requirements. Eligible donor banks must have all necessary licenses, certifications, and registrations to operate a cord blood stem cell bank. They must also have proper donor screening and collection practices to protect donors and recipients. The eligible cord blood stem cell bank must have proper donor screening, collection practices, and confidentiality measures to protect donors and recipients. The eligible cord blood stem cell bank must ensure confidentiality, diversity in donors, and communication with other banks. The eligible cord blood stem cell bank must encourage donation by a diverse group of donors and have systems for communication with other banks, transplant centers, and physicians for the distribution of cord blood units. The eligible cord blood stem cell bank must comply with regulations under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, track recipients' outcomes, and educate the public about the benefits of donating cord blood stem cells. The Secretary will establish a Board of Directors to administer the National Cord Blood Stem Cell Bank Network, including creating a national cord blood stem cell registry and coordinating donor banks. The Board of Directors for the National Cord Blood Stem Cell Bank Network will be appointed by the Secretary and will include representatives from cord blood stem cell transplant centers and physicians from participating birthing hospitals.
